item.title: $1.75 trillion is plenty of money to write a good Build Back Better bill
item.description:
I don‚Äôt have a lot to say about the latest blowup between Joe Manchin and Democratic Party leaders over Build Back Better except to say that I think the whole notion of ‚Äúleverage‚Äù in this situation is a farce. Joe Biden carried 25 states in 2020, and those states send 47 Democratic Party Senators to Washington. It is very lucky for progressives that Jon Tester and Sherrod Brown choose not to espouse significant deviations from the Biden agenda (though Democrats may come to regret that if those seats flip GOP in 2024), and they are also lucky that Joe Manchin is much more progressive than the median voter in West Virginia‚Ä¶

URL: https://www.slowboring.com/p/175-trillion-is-plenty-of-money-to?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

source: John Holbo on the Persistent Structures of "Establishment Wisdom"

item.title: GOP governors' covid messaging is a mess. Even Trump seems like a leader by comparison.
item.description:
Longtime readers are probably aware that I‚Äôm not a big fan of former President Donald Trump. But I also try to give credit where it is due. And this week, Trump has emerged as an unlikely voice of Republican sanity, such as it is, when it comes to Covid vaccines‚Ä¶

item.title: A Powerful, Implied Indictment in the New York Times
item.description:
This newsletter is going to be just a bit different, especially for a piece so close to Christmas. But it‚Äôs about a topic of particular concern, and one that deserves more attention. It‚Äôs about our war on terror, how we fought, and why‚Äîdespite all of our mistakes‚Äîour enemies bear the moral responsib‚Ä¶

item.title: Personnel Isn't Policy, Policy Is Personnel
item.description:
I‚Äôm back! Even though this newsletter is free, I feel bad about not writing. What‚Äôs going on, uhhh, since the beginning of the year has not been conducive to thinking about the subjects I want to write about or really much thinking at all. Despite that, there‚Äôs actually been an influx of new subscribers, taking the total to over 1,000, which is thrillin‚Ä¶

URL: https://zeitlin.substack.com/p/personnel-isnt-policy-policy-is-personnel?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

item.title: The Actual War on Christmas
item.description:
Well, fuck. There goes another Christmas. I‚Äôm writing this from London, where the Omicron variant is absolutely everywhere. These past few days the city has been gradually unpeopling. The coffee shop we go to every morning was almost empty, and that‚Äôs almost unheard of - it‚Äôs a community hub - and at the end of the day they shut their doors. Everyone is sick, or knows somebody who is. Everything is muffled under a torch-through-a- blanket sky. In retrospect, when a bunch of incompetent aristocrats promised us a staggering global catastrophe would be over by Christmas, we might have known not to believe them‚Ä¶

URL: https://lauriepenny.substack.com/p/the-actual-war-on-christmas?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

source: Understanding Our Current Price-Level Surge

item.title: Notes on a Remarkable Finding from Finland
item.description:
I recently came across a paper by Ursina Schaede and Ville Mankki that contains a fascinating empirical finding with major implications for the way in which we think about meritocracy. The paper examines the long run effects on students of a change in the manner in which their teachers were selected into a graduate program. Finland is well known for hav‚Ä¶

URL: https://rajivsethi.substack.com/p/notes-on-a-remarkable-finding-from?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

source: Understanding Our Current Price-Level Surge
